instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message: Hey guys working on on this 820-3435 air no water damage, customer used the mac one morning and shut it down came back to use it and it would not turn on. iItried smc reset at first but noting happened, green light did not cycle from green to orange. Tried this twice with no luck that's when i started to check the rails. Is the smc at fault, or is it something else telling the smc to power cycle SMC_PM_G2_EN.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message: Did you try a new battery? I'd try that and if not plug in charger with battery unplugged just to rule it out

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message:
Why would a battery fix this? It power on fine without battery.

Is the green/orange light present? PPBUS voltage? S5_PWRGD pulsing high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message: I've had boards that don't turn on in with a bad battery plugged in that's the only reason I thought it could cause issues.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27427"]Why would a battery fix this? It power on fine without battery.

Is the green/orange light present? PPBUS voltage? S5_PWRGD pulsing high?[/QUOTE]

Charger light is present and solid Pbus Voltage steady 8.59 S5_PWRGD is pulsing hi 3.3v

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message: All boards will turn on if the correct charger is used. So always use 85W REAL ORIGINAL chargers for testing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message: This is usually the SMC or U7501.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-3435 SMC_PM_G2_EN Power Cycling  U7501
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27444"]This is usually the SMC or U7501.[/QUOTE]

Once again Duke right on the money replaced U7501 back to life mark as solved !
